channel.title: The New York Times Trends
channel.description: 用中文浏览纽约时报热门报道

item.title: State Representative Summer Lee, a progressive Democrat, won a House primary in Pennsylvania on Friday after three days of vote-counting. She could become the first Black woman to represent the state in Congress. https://t.co/1FMVyTCyAR

Tesla’s shares have declined more than 40% since April 4, vaporizing more than $400 billion in stock market value — and Elon Musk has not helped by turning his bid to buy Twitter into a financial soap opera. https://t.co/jr5HyXfm6Y

The conservative lawyer John Eastman, the architect of a strategy to overturn the 2020 election, dealt directly with Donald Trump and received handwritten notes from him as the men sought to keep Trump in power, according to a new court filing. https://t.co/KV1xdhY0cR

A street inside New York City’s only Army base will soon bear the name of First Lt. John Earl Warren Jr., a Black officer who died saving others in Vietnam — instead of the name of the Confederate general who led the South’s attempt at secession. https://t.co/GNhn27ZHi4

The G7 agreed to provide nearly $20 billion to Ukraine over the coming months to help keep its government running.
“We will continue to stand by Ukraine throughout this war and beyond and are prepared to do more as needed,” a joint statement said. https://t.co/PnulHb4uc7

The membership list of the “Friends of Stone” group chat, provided to The New York Times by one of its participants, offers a kind of road map of Roger Stone’s links to a large number of people who sought to overturn the 2020 election. https://t.co/dOy7XPxEO4

Russia appeared to be laying the groundwork Thursday for annexing swaths of southeast Ukraine, with officials already moving to introduce the ruble currency and install proxy politicians in local governments. https://t.co/4hbi9OcIvY

Rep. Hakeem Jeffries, the second-highest-ranking Black lawmaker in Congress, has launched an effort to discredit a proposed congressional map that would divide historically Black neighborhoods in New York, likening its configurations to Jim Crow tactics. https://t.co/3n7hb0lrlN

New evidence — including three videos obtained by The New York Times — shows how Russian paratroopers rounded up and executed at least eight Ukrainian men in Bucha on March 4, a likely war crime. https://t.co/mgWmJYgPJF https://t.co/ZGrldnhht6

Current and former Wells Fargo employees said that they were instructed by their bosses or human resources managers to interview “diverse” candidates — even though the decision had already been made to give the job to another candidate. https://t.co/DxCVvxF4GU

The three known remaining survivors of the 1921 massacre that saw a white mob kill hundreds of Black residents in Tulsa, Oklahoma, received a $1 million donation from a philanthropic group frustrated that the justice system has yet to compensate them. https://t.co/McacHMMpX6
Breaking News: The Senate overwhelmingly approved $40 billion in aid to Ukraine, bringing the total U.S. war investment to $54 billion in about two months. https://t.co/ulei0HD1W0

Breaking News: The U.S. officially surpassed one million known deaths from Covid-19 on Thursday, according to a New York Times database. The milestone comes amid a growing wave of cases. https://t.co/gIAuFxic18 https://t.co/5hSV8ikEDE
Puberty is starting earlier than it used to for some girls. Scientists aren’t sure why, but they’re studying the potential role of obesity, chemicals and stress. https://t.co/fhQtZWZdZP

New evidence — including three videos obtained by The New York Times — shows how Russian paratroopers rounded up and executed at least eight Ukrainian men in Bucha on March 4, a likely war crime. https://t.co/EnA2q943Ds https://t.co/BRMDeGo0u6

Germany’s former chancellor, Gerhard Schröder, will lose his government-funded office because of his unwillingness to quit his lobbying posts with Russian energy companies and distance himself from Vladimir Putin, a parliamentary committee said Thursday. https://t.co/hQyWAlZcMX

In 2012, the photographer Matika Wilbur, who is Swinomish and Tulalip, packed her cameras, sold everything and bought her RV, she named “Big Girl.” She spent the next decade on the road attempting to photograph every federally recognized tribe in the U.S. https://t.co/zfuW4n2Pa2 https://t.co/pGW8pmJjdb
Breaking News: Oklahoma lawmakers passed a bill banning nearly all abortions starting at fertilization, which would make it the nation’s strictest abortion law. https://t.co/XcR8XudXyp

A day of reckoning has arrived for some people and their dogs after two years of 24/7 togetherness. As more remote workers return to the office, the transition could be a challenge for owners and pets alike. https://t.co/7SYTmU9NPH https://t.co/mX7yk7HjoQ

The Senate voted unanimously on Wednesday to confirm Bridget Brink to be the U.S. ambassador to Ukraine, filling a position that has remained empty for more than a year. The move came hours after the U.S. reopened its embassy in Kyiv. https://t.co/cfBe3HSJMm https://t.co/f1QviIcE69

One third of Americans live in areas where the threat of Covid is now so high that they should consider wearing a mask in indoor public settings, whether local leaders require it or not, federal health officials warned. https://t.co/MDAOZJfIGB https://t.co/cg3e40PhOh

In Opinion
“It was only on the battlefields of World War II that fascism was defeated,” writes Timothy Snyder, a history professor, in a guest essay. “Now it’s back — and this time, the country fighting a fascist war of destruction is Russia.” https://t.co/GEyTHDQuuy

An official in Japan mistakenly wired a rural town’s entire Covid relief budget, nearly $360,000, to a single recipient. After promising to return the cash, the police said, the man gambled it away in online casinos. https://t.co/Y4z3mBg3To

A giant freshwater stingray was rescued and released along the Mekong River in Cambodia after getting caught on a fisherman’s line earlier this month. The endangered creature was 13 feet long and weighed 400 pounds. https://t.co/SMJgEwUMEL https://t.co/UZG3auunN7

Two strongmen leaders are hindering Europe's efforts to stand up to Vladimir Putin. President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey is blocking the NATO applications of Sweden and Finland, and Prime Minister Viktor Orban of Hungary is blocking an EU embargo. https://t.co/09Q85fg3TF
Here's a look at the toll long Covid takes inside the body — and why it can be so debilitating. https://t.co/6xt8oeohE0

A group trying to hold lawyers accountable for their efforts to keep Donald Trump in power after his 2020 election loss filed a complaint against Senator Ted Cruz with the Texas bar association. https://t.co/7AGrITEiRp

Rosmarie Trapp, a member of the singing family made famous by “The Sound of Music” and the last surviving daughter of the baron and the would-be nun depicted in the stage musical and 1965 film, has died. She was 93. https://t.co/zWflwtwRh9

A Massachusetts man has been diagnosed with the monkeypox virus, a rare and potentially fatal disease. The case, the first in the U.S. this year, follows a series of unusual clusters in other countries that have begun to alarm health officials. https://t.co/kW11otfnWu

The Ukrainian fighters who surrendered to Russian forces at a steel plant in Mariupol are entitled to protection under the Geneva Conventions as prisoners of war, legal experts said. A convention states they cannot be prosecuted only for fighting in a war. https://t.co/2MwXwsLlvq

A giant freshwater stingray was rescued and released along the Mekong River in Cambodia after getting caught on a fisherman’s line earlier this month. The endangered creature was 13 feet long and weighed 400 pounds. https://t.co/fRc66mxP9N https://t.co/UbyDnIRpHY

Breaking News: President Biden invoked the Defense Production Act to increase baby formula supplies and offered U.S. planes to speed shipments from abroad as the country faces a shortage that has sown fear and frustration among parents. https://t.co/PrTJzvHNXY

President Biden formally endorsed Finland and Sweden’s applications to join NATO on Wednesday, while also issuing a carefully-worded warning to Russia that the U.S. would help defend the countries in the interim before they become members. https://t.co/Cbq3uKvAdZ

Breaking News: More than 75% of long Covid patients in the U.S. were not hospitalized when they were first infected — yet months later, they were experiencing symptoms that were diagnosed as post-Covid conditions, a large study found. https://t.co/olGbuOYMt8

Breaking News: A third of Americans live in areas with such high Covid levels now that they should consider wearing masks indoors whether local leaders require it or not, U.S. health officials warned. https://t.co/emLWdlZ7eN
Breaking News: Turkey blocked NATO’s initial effort to fast-track Finland’s and Sweden’s applications to join the alliance, according to a senior diplomat. https://t.co/WTrg4uwz1U

Breaking News: A Russian soldier pleaded guilty in Kyiv to shooting a civilian, in the first Ukrainian trial over a potential war crime since Russia’s invasion.
Asked if he accepted his guilt, the soldier said: “Yes. Fully yes.” https://t.co/9Wd9cE0jdI

About 30 minutes before he opened fire at a Buffalo supermarket, the gunman in Saturday's shooting invited a small group of people to join a chat room on Discord where he had spent months planning the massacre. No one appeared to have alerted the police. https://t.co/DPvK99gZr3

Finland and Sweden formally asked to join NATO on Wednesday after decades of strategic neutrality. Both countries have seen public opinion tilt heavily in favor of becoming members of the alliance since Russia’s invasion of Ukraine. https://t.co/CRT6Apj4pm https://t.co/3eosqhkaEG

It’s difficult to catch Asian elephants responding to deaths of herd members in the wild. So researchers turned to YouTube.
Videos showed the animals touching or trying to lift carcasses. Often, the elephants kept a kind of vigil over their fallen peers. https://t.co/rz1QaUqBAq

Rep. Madison Cawthorn lost the Republican primary in North Carolina's 11th District on Tuesday. The outcome served as a rebuke of Cawthorn, a right-wing firebrand and the youngest freshman in Congress, who was once seen as a rising Republican star. https://t.co/S6b2efK3dl https://t.co/Q5xw0VEoZX
Kaja Kallas, Estonia’s prime minister, remembers life under Soviet occupation. She has become one of Europe’s toughest voices against Russia for its war in Ukraine. https://t.co/FjA8fjsmmY

President Biden paid tribute to each of the victims of the racist massacre in Buffalo. He choked up as he said one of the victims was a father visiting the supermarket to buy a birthday cake for his 3-year-old son.
"Evil will not win, I promise you." https://t.co/umNDlTv50W

A military analyst on Russian state television left other panelists in stunned silence when he said that the conflict in Ukraine was deteriorating for Russia, giving the kind of honest assessment that is virtually banished from the official airwaves. https://t.co/bnhNCRplOR

Breaking News: Finland and Sweden formally asked to join NATO, casting aside decades of neutrality after Russia’s invasion of Ukraine upended European security.
https://t.co/LbLHJdVr5K

Hundreds of Ukrainian soldiers who made a last stand against Russian forces from a Mariupol steel mill faced an uncertain future Tuesday under Kremlin custody. They were transported to Russian-held territory aboard buses emblazoned with “Z." https://t.co/cfXE2DKpvW

Biniam Girmay of Eritrea became the first Black African cyclist to win a stage of one of the Grand Tours. “It’s unbelievable,” he said after he won the 10th stage of the Giro d’Italia. https://t.co/J6W2DEOupt

President Biden condemned the racist rhetoric that reportedly influenced a white man to gun down Black shoppers at the Tops supermarket in Buffalo. “What happened here is simple and straightforward: Terrorism. Terrorism. Domestic terrorism,” Biden said. https://t.co/7PQuMUnLXs https://t.co/xGFlqAMCmD
Breaking News: Rep. Madison Cawthorn lost his Republican primary in North Carolina after a series of incendiary statements and scandals soured many former supporters. https://t.co/Gii86HK9gh

Christian Cooper is perhaps best known for his encounter in Central Park with a white woman who called 911 to falsely accuse him of threatening her. Now, he'll be back in the public eye — this time hosting a new show for National Geographic. https://t.co/tXjrBmTu6h
